contextId.information: Here Paul speaks of "God's judgment" as if it were alive and could "fall" on people. AT: "God will judge those people truly and fairly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: God's judgment is according to truth when it falls on those

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the law here as if it were alive and had its own voice. AT: "everything that the law says people should do is for" or "all the commands that Moses wrote in the law are for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: whatever the law says, it speaks to

contextId.information: The words "the law and the Prophets" refer to the parts of scripture that Moses and the prophets wrote in the Jewish scriptures. Paul describes them here as if they were people testifying in court. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "What Moses and the prophets wrote confirms this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: It was witnessed by the law and the Prophets

contextId.information: Paul uses personification here as he speaks of "confidence" as if it were alive. AT: "We are very confident that we will receive the things that we wait for" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: This confidence does not disappoint

contextId.information: Paul describes sin as a dangerous thing that came into the world through the actions of "one man," Adam. This sin then became an opening through which death, pictured here as another dangerous thing, also came into the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: through one man sin entered ... death entered through sin

contextId.information: Paul is speaking of death as if it were a king who ruled. AT: "people continued to die from the time of Adam until the time of Moses as a consequence of their sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: death ruled from Adam until Moses

contextId.information: Here Paul speaks of "death" as a king who ruled. The "rule" of death causes everyone to die. AT: "everyone died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: death ruled

contextId.information: Here "death" is described as a king or ruler that has power over people. AT: "He can never die again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Death no longer rules over him

contextId.information: Paul describes sin as a person's king or master. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: do not let sin rule ... Do not allow sin to rule

contextId.information: Paul speaks of "sin" here as if it were a king who rules over people. AT: "Do not let sinful desires control what you do" or "Do not allow yourselves to do the sinful things you want to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Do not allow sin to rule over you

contextId.information: Paul is comparing sin to a person who can act. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: I would never have known sin, if it were not through the law ... But sin took the opportunity ... brought about every lust

contextId.information: This can mean 1) "I realized that I was sinning" (UDB) or 2) "I strongly desired to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: sin regained life

contextId.information: As in [[:en:bible:notes:rom:07:07|7:7-8]], Paul is describing sin as a person who can do 3 things: take the opportunity, deceive, and kill. AT: "Because I wanted to sin, I deceived myself into thinking that I could sin and obey the commandment at the same time, but God punished me for disobeying the commandment by separating me from him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: For sin took the opportunity through the commandment and deceived me. Through the commandment it killed me

contextId.information: Paul is comparing sin to a person who can act. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rom:07:07|7:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: took the opportunity through the commandment

contextId.information: Paul describes sin as a living being that has the power to influence him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the sin that lives in me

contextId.information: Paul speaks of "sin" as if it were alive and living inside him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: rather sin that lives in me

contextId.information: Here the law is described as a person who could not break the power of sin. AT: "For the law did not have the power to stop us from sinning, because the power of sin within us was too strong. But God did stop us from sinning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: For what the law was unable to do because it was weak through the flesh, God did

contextId.information: Here Paul speaks of both the "flesh" and the "spirit" as if they were living persons. AT: "the way sinful people think ... the way people who listen to the Holy Spirit think" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the mentality of the flesh ... the mentality of the Spirit

contextId.information: Paul describes everything that God created as a person who eagerly waits for something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the eager expectation of the creation waits for

contextId.information: Here the scripture is personified as if God were talking to Pharaoh. AT: "The scripture records that God said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: For the scripture says

contextId.information: Here "righteousness" is described as a person who can speak. AT: "But Moses writes this about how faith makes a person right before God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: But the righteousness that comes from faith says this

contextId.information: The word "it" refers to "the righteousness" of [[:en:bible:notes:rom:10:06|10:6]]. Here Paul describes "righteousness" as a person who can speak. Paul uses a question to emphasize the answer he is about to give. AT: "But this is what Moses says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But what does it say?

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the Scripture as if it were alive and had a voice. You can make explicit who wrote the Scripture that Paul uses here. AT: "For Isaiah wrote in the Scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For scripture says

contextId.information: Paul speaks of "severity" as if it were alive and in motion. You can make explicit that God had to deal harshly with the Jewish people. AT: "God dealt harshly with the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]],[[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: severity came on the Jews

contextId.information: This phrase portrays love as a person who is being kind to other people. AT: "People who love their neighbors do not harm them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Love does not harm one's neighbor

contextId.information: Here Paul speaks of the Roman believers' obedience as if it were a person who could go to people. AT: "For everyone has heard how you obey Jesus" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: For your example of obedience reaches everyone
